title: Frank Brown (footballer, born 1890)
text:
Frank Brown (born 1890) was an English <a href="association%20football">football</a> player and manager.
Brown began his football career with <a href="Barnsley%20F.C.">Barnsley</a> in 1910, moving to <a href="Rotherham%20County%20F.C.">Rotherham County</a> in 1914 and then to <a href="Huddersfield%20Town%20A.F.C.">Huddersfield Town</a> in 1915. In August 1919 he joined <a href="Blackpool%20F.C.">Blackpool</a>, but struggled to break into the first team and left to join <a href="Exeter%20City%20F.C.">Exeter City</a> in May 1921. He stayed only one season at St. James' Park, moving to <a href="Pontypridd%20F.C.">Pontypridd</a> in June 1922 before returning to <a href="Devon">Devon</a> and joining <a href="Torquay%20United%20F.C.">Torquay United</a> in 1923.
He retired prior to Torquay achieving league status, but became the club's trainer and with <a href="Percy%20Mackrill">Percy Mackrill</a> in charge saw United elected to the <a href="English%20Football%20League">Football League</a>. In May 1932 he was appointed manager of Torquay United, and during his six seasons at the helm at <a href="Plainmoor">Plainmoor</a>, Torquay finished 10th 3 times, and 20th (out of 22 teams) 3 times.
In May 1938, Brown moved to the manager's chair at <a href="Chester%20City%20F.C.">Chester</a>, leading them to 6th place in <a href="Division%20Three%20%28North%29">Division Three (North)</a> and a second replay against <a href="Sheffield%20Wednesday%20F.C.">Sheffield Wednesday</a> in the 4th round of the <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> in his first season. The <a href="World%20War%20II">war</a> intervened in September 1939 with Chester unbeaten after 3 games of the new season, and Chester joined a regional league alongside the likes of <a href="Manchester%20United%20F.C.">Manchester United</a>, <a href="Liverpool%20F.C.">Liverpool</a>, <a href="Everton%20F.C.">Everton</a> and <a href="Manchester%20City%20F.C.">Manchester City</a>. When league football resumed, Chester finished the 1946–47 season in 3rd place and won the <a href="Welsh%20Cup">Welsh Cup</a> the same year. However, the following seasons saw mid-table finishes at best as he struggled with the limited resources available. He eventually left Chester in May 1953, and was manager of <a href="Stafford%20Rangers%20F.C.">Stafford Rangers</a> in 1954–55.
He died shortly after finishing his football managerial career.
